Award.AwardTitle: Assessing Ecosystem Carbon Dynamics over North America by Integrating Eddy Covariance, MODIS, and New Ecological Data through Upscaling and Model-Data Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate descriptions of the carbon budget at regional to global scales would improve our understanding of feedbacks between the land and climate and would be of substantial assistance in policy making in the climate area. Although there is general agreement that North America is a large sink for carbon, the size and distribution of this sink are not well known and there are large uncertainties in its variation in space and time. Recent measurements of local carbon fluxes using fast and accurate technology, development of new computer models and techniques, and improvements in the retrieval and analysis of satellite information, have created new opportunities. This project will capitalize on these advances in several ways. The project will integrate continuous local carbon flux observations made at the tops of towers, satellite and aircraft remote sensing data, and new data on important ecosystems of the country (such as the amount of plant mass and nitrogen content). Advanced methods will be used to merge the ground and remote information into models that consider its distribution in space and dynamics in time. Analysis of the uncertainties involved will also be conducted of the data and the models. The results will include estimates of carbon sinks and sources on land and identification of what affects them from year to year, with particular focus on extreme conditions, such as severe droughts, wildfires, or timber harvesting.

This work will provide a new benchmark for the amount and dynamics of carbon in North American ecosystems. The results will be of use in national climate change assessments, especially because extreme climate events and other disturbances are generally projected to be more severe and frequent in the future. The project will also develop methods that are more generally useful and that could be adapted by environmental observation networks and used for making and evaluating predictions of future conditions. Release of project data and results to other scientists will be done through participation of the project scientists in meetings and publications. The work will also contribute to several education activities aimed at high school education and teacher training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goals of our work are to advance towards data-driven diagnostics of continental-scale carbon fluxes using a synthesis of eddy flux measurements, MODIS data, and new spatial data through upscaling and model-data fusion, and to assess the magnitude, distribution, and variability of ecosystem carbon exchange across North America over the period 2000-2012.

The major project findings that address the intellectual merit include:

(1) The mean annual gross primary productivity (GPP), ecosystem respiration (ER), and net ecosystem productivity (NEP) of the U.S. over the period 2001-2012 were 6.84, 5.31, and 1.10 Pg C yr-1, respectively; the mean annual GPP, ER, and NEP of Canada over the same 12-year period were 3.91, 3.26, and 0.60 Pg C yr-1, respectively. The mean nationwide annual NEP of natural ecosystems over the period 2001-2012 was 0.53 Pg C yr-1 for the U.S. and 0.49 Pg C yr-1 for the conterminous U.S. Biomass burning emissions were not included in our estimate. If fire emissions (0.06 Pg C yr-1) were deducted from our estimate, then the size of the carbon sink for the conterminous U.S. was 0.47 Pg C yr-1, which was 17.5% lower than our previous estimate (0.57 Pg C yr-1). Our estimate was similar to the estimate (0.49 pg C yr-1) of the first North American State of the Carbon Cycle Report (SOCCR).

(2) The carbon fluxes over North America exhibited relatively large interannual variability over the study period from 2000 to 2012. Our results show that drought and disturbances had substantial impacts on carbon fluxes at regional to continental scales. The main sources of the interannual variability included drought and disturbance. Our gridded flux estimates provided an independent, alternative perspective on ecosystem carbon exchange over North America compared to inventory approaches, ecosystem models, and atmospheric inversions.

(3) We generalized the forest ecosystem model – PnET-CN to be applicable to other biome types. We determined parameter values for grasslands and shrublands using the literature and ecophysiological databases. Our results show that PnET-CN is a promising tool for modeling ecosystem carbon and water fluxes for non-forest biomes (grasslands, shrublands, and savannas), and especially for modeling GPP in mature biomes. Future modifications of PnET-CN for non-forest sites should focus on belowground processes, including water storage in dry shrubland soils, root growth and respiration in grasslands, and soil carbon fluxes for all biomes.

(4) We used a process-based forest ecosystem model, PnET-CN, to evaluate how, and by what mechanisms, clear-cuts alter ecosystem carbon fluxes, aboveground carbon stocks (AGC), and leaf area index (LAI) in northern temperate forests. The decline of NEP with age was caused by the relative flattening of GPP and gradual increase of ER. Evergreen needleleaf forests (ENF) recovered more slowly from a net carbon source to a net sink, and lost more carbon than deciduous broadleaf forests (DBF). This suggests that ENF is in general may be slower to recover to full carbon assimilation capacity after stand-replacing harvests, arising from slower development of photosynthesis with stand age. Model results indicated that increased harvesting intensity would delay the recovery of NEP after clear-cuts, but this had little effect on C dynamics during late succession.

(5) We used a simple ecosystem model, eddy covariance flux observations, and a model-data fusion approach to assess the uncertainty of regional carbon flux estimates for the Upper Midwest region of northern Wisconsin and Michigan, USA. Our model-data fusion approach can effectively estimate the parameters of the diagnostic carbon flux model using flux observations from 16 eddy covariance flux sites in the study region. Over the period from 2001-2007, the mean annual net ecosystem exchange of carbon dioxide (NEE) of the study region was estimated to be -30.0 Tg C yr-1, and the associated uncertainty as measured by standard deviation was ±7.6 Tg C yr-1. Uncertainty in parameters can lead to large uncertainty to estimates of regional carbon fluxes, and our model-data approach can provide uncertainty bounds to regional carbon fluxes.

This project has led to 15 publications in professional journals with 2 manuscripts in preparation.

Project outcomes that address broader impacts are as follows:

This project provides training opportunities for two postdoctoral research associates, two visiting PhD students, and two visiting scholars. Our work contributes to education activities aimed at K-12 carbon cycle science education activity conducted in coordination with the NSF GLOBE program and teacher training in carbon cycling, climate change, and broad-scale ecology. We have been disseminating our scientific results to the research community by presenting our results at professional meetings and publishing the results in professional journals. We have also shared our continental-scale flux product and our generalized PnET-CN model with the research community by making our data products and model code available through ftp and our group website.
